page.title: 15Wormleighton the boundaries
page.content: There are of course boundaries made by roads running through the area and the hedgerows are usually interspersed with trees. A feature found here is the double hedgerow between fields also interplanted with hardwood trees. In many places this was the recognised method of marking county boundaries but around Wormleighton the purpose of these was to provide timber. In a letter to Cardinal Wolsey's Commission of Enguiry of 1517 John Spencer wrote "There was no wood nor timber growing within twelve or fourteen miles and the poor folk had to burn the straw that their cattle should live by". John Spencer was therefor the originator of the double boundaries still in existence today.
